user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemFlush:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemFlush(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_BinSemFlush_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemFlush:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_BinSemFlush_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /* Lock the mutex ( not the table! ) */
    if (OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(&sem->id) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* increment the flush counter.  Any other threads that are
     * currently pending in SemTake() will see the counter change and
     * return _without_ modifying the semaphore count.
     */
    ++sem->flush_request;

    /* unblock all threads that are be waiting on this sem */
    pthread_cond_broadcast(&(sem->cv));

    pthread_mutex_unlock(&(sem->id));

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code fragments were identified in the provided snippets. Rationale:

- OS_BinSemFlush: The only conditional is if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) which is dependent on the runtime result of OS_ObjectIdGetById; the call to OS_BinSemFlush_Impl is therefore potentially reachable. The final return return_code is reachable on all paths.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Early return after OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit failure is an intended, reachable error path. The subsequent code (OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, token->obj_id assignment, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken) is only executed when the previous step succeeds; the error-path call to OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token) is reachable when return_code != OS_SUCCESS. No statements occur after an unconditional return that would make them dead.

- OS_BinSemFlush_Impl: The early return on mutex-acquire failure (return OS_SEM_FAILURE) is a reachable runtime path; the remainder of the function (increment flush_request, pthread_cond_broadcast, pthread_mutex_unlock, return OS_SUCCESS) is executed when the mutex is acquired. There are no statements after an unconditional return in a block that would be unreachable.

- No constant-condition constructs, unreachable labels, #if 0 blocks, or other constructs that would produce statically unreachable code are present in the shown code. Macros used (e.g., OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) are used in expressions and do not imply unreachable code in the provided context.

Therefore, based on the supplied code, there are no fragments that obviously violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (no unreachable code). If additional files/macros or preprocessor conditionals exist outside the provided snippets, those should be reviewed separately.
